content:
There are a myriad of possible causes. And "not responding" issues have plagued Thunderbird for a long time. Generally these issues come for folk not compacting their storage, or the compact failing to complete.

Or contention issues getting access to the storage files to actually perform the function. This is also a leading cause of compact failures.

The leading cause of these contention issues is the ubiquitous antivirus product that is scanning this huge file every time it changes. They are inherently slow, taking something like 10 minutes per gigabyte. Lots of folk have an inbox that is more than a few Gigbytes in size and updated every 10 minutes or so. Then updates again to remove junk, move mails or delete them using filters (two more updates) all before you the user actually get a look at the mail to interact with it.

The upshot is we recommend you exclude the Thunderbird mail and IMAPmail folders, but preferably the entire Thunderbird profile folder, from this on access scanning to prevent this contention.

There are detailed diagnostic steps here https://wiki.mozilla.org/Thunderbird:Testing:Memory_Usage_Problems They are show in relation to memory there, but really they are fairly generic.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
You get the incoming (IMAP or POP) addresses and the outgoing (SMTP) addresses from the Mailfence and GMail sites. The necessary ports to use and the security settings will be found at the same sources.

Google "setting up a GMail account" and "setting up a Mailfence account" if you can't find the addresses, ports, and security settings at GMail.com and Mailfence.com.

content: A simple approach would be to create separate profiles for each (which could be copied from the current PC) and place a desktop icon for each person on desktop. Rightclick on icon and in the 'target' box, enter this: C:\program files\Thunderbird\thunderbird.exe -profilemgr "your location of profile"
creator: davidsk

content: I suppose in that scenario (if each user had their own Desktop) they would only see their own icon, and Thunderbird should only ever be opened from one or the other shortcut icons?

content: If they each have their own desktop, they should be fine.
creator: davidsk

content:
Reverting to a prior version is iffy, but this often works: - exit thunderbird - in the computer search box on taskbar, type: 'Run' 

   select the 'Run' app    Enter: thunderbird.exe -P --allow-downgrade    click on 'OK'

If you want to test with beta in future, I suggest not upgrading the release version, but let the beta upgrade to a coexisting location.
creator: davidsk

content: As @wisewiz indicated, there is no way to convert POP to IMAP (or the reverse), but you can have POP and IMAP accounts on the same version of Thunderbird. That is, you don't need a separate PC for the IMAP setup.
